perturbation.original_text: Each Party agrees that to the extent such Party is the beneficiary of a Future Affiliate Provision, such Party hereby waives and disclaims, and will not seek to enforce or claim the benefit of, such Future Affiliate Provision, such waiver, disclaimer and covenant being for the sole benefit of the other Parties, their Party Groups, and their future Affiliates.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party may consider waiving a Future Affiliate Provision to the extent it deems appropriate; however, such waiver is not guaranteed and depends on various factors.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a clear obligation to waive Future Affiliate Provisions. The modified text introduces ambiguity and discretion, replacing 'agrees' with 'may consider' and adding subjective criteria ('to the extent it deems appropriate', 'not guaranteed'). This creates uncertainty about the actual obligation, which weakens the enforceability of the original clause.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Enforceability of Contracts. Ambiguous terms can render a contract provision unenforceable due to lack of mutual assent or definiteness.

perturbation.original_text: Otis and Carrier, on behalf of themselves and the other members of, respectively, the Otis Group and the Carrier Group, agree and promise to assist UTC and the other members of the UTC Group, at UTC's request, in UTC's discretion and at UTC's cost, in applying for, registering, maintaining, renewing, demonstrating use of, recording UTC's and the other members of the UTC Group's rights in, and otherwise perfecting, and defending and enforcing against third party infringers, the rights of UTC and the other members of the UTC Group in the United Technologies Trademarks and all goodwill associated therewith, including executing, verifying, acknowledging and delivering any and all documents, including any instruments of transfer and recordable assignments, and confirmations of use, and performing such other acts deemed necessary in the reasonable opinion of UTC.
perturbation.changed_text: Otis and Carrier may, at their convenience, assist UTC in protecting its United Technologies Trademarks, as long as it doesn't significantly impact their own business operations.
perturbation.explanation: This modification replaces a clear and mandatory obligation ('agree and promise to assist') with a discretionary one ('may assist'). The added condition about not significantly impacting their own business operations introduces further ambiguity and allows Otis and Carrier to potentially avoid their obligation based on a subjective assessment of impact.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trademark Law - Duty to Protect Trademarks. While not a direct violation, weakening the obligation to assist in protecting trademarks can indirectly undermine UTC's ability to enforce its trademark rights, potentially conflicting with trademark law principles.

perturbation.original_text: Each of the licenses granted in Section 3.1.1, subject to the restrictions of Section 3.1.2 and Section 3.1.3, includes the right of a Licensee Party and other members of the Licensee Group to make improvements to such Licensed Intellectual Property Rights. Neither a Licensor Party nor any member of the Licensor Group will have any rights to any such improvements, and as between a Licensee Party and a Licensor Party, the Licensee Party or applicable member of the Licensee Group will own all such improvements made by the Licensee Party or such member of the Licensee Group to Licensed Intellectual Property Rights.
perturbation.changed_text: Each of the licenses granted in Section 3.1.1, subject to the restrictions of Section 3.1.2 and Section 3.1.3, includes the possible right of a Licensee Party to attempt to make improvements to such Licensed Intellectual Property Rights. The ownership of such improvements will be determined on a case-by-case basis based on contribution.
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly states that the licensee has the right to make improvements, and owns any such improvements. The modified text introduces ambiguity by changing 'includes the right' to 'includes the possible right to attempt', making the right to improve uncertain. Furthermore, it replaces the clear ownership rule with a vague 'case-by-case basis based on contribution' standard, creating uncertainty about who owns the improvements. This could discourage innovation and lead to disputes.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Patent/Copyright Law - Ownership of Intellectual Property. The ambiguity contradicts the principle that ownership of intellectual property should be clearly defined.
